description: Master the art of recording transactions through journal entries, understanding T-Accounts, General and Subsidiary Ledgers, and preparing adjusting and closing entries

slides.title: Welcome to Journal Entries & Ledgers
slides.content:
# Journal Entries and Ledgers

Journal entries are the **foundation of recording** every business transaction. Ledgers organize these entries by account.

## What You Will Learn

- **Recording Transactions** - The journal entry format
- **General and Subsidiary Ledgers** - Organizing accounts
- **T-Accounts** - Visual representation of accounts
- **Adjusting and Closing Entries** - Period-end procedures

## The Recording Process Flow

```
Source Document
      |
      v
   Journal
      |
      v
   Ledger
      |
      v
Trial Balance
      |
      v
Financial Statements
```

## Why This Matters

| Benefit | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| Accuracy | Proper recording prevents errors |
| Audit Trail | Documentation of all transactions |
| Organization | Easy to find specific accounts |
| Compliance | Meets regulatory requirements |

> **Fun Fact:** The journal is called the "book of original entry" because it is where transactions are first recorded!

slides.title: The General Journal
slides.content:
# The General Journal

## What is a Journal?

A journal is the **chronological record** of all business transactions. Each entry includes the date, accounts affected, amounts, and a brief description.

## Journal Entry Format

```
Date       Account Title               Debit     Credit
---------------------------------------------------------
Jan 15    Cash                         5,000
             Service Revenue                      5,000
          (Received cash for services)
```

## Rules for Journal Entries

### 1. Date
- Record the date of the transaction

### 2. Debits First
- List debit accounts first
- Amounts in debit column

### 3. Credits Indented
- Credit accounts are indented
- Amounts in credit column

### 4. Description
- Brief explanation in parentheses
- Also called narration

### 5. Balance
- Total debits MUST equal total credits

## Example Entry Breakdown

```
Jan 20    Equipment                   10,000
             Cash                                 4,000
             Notes Payable                        6,000
          (Purchased equipment, paid part
           cash, balance on note)
```

This is a **compound entry** - more than two accounts affected.

> **Remember:** Debits on top, credits indented below!

slides.title: Common Journal Entry Examples
slides.content:
# Journal Entry Examples

## 1. Owner Investment

Owner invests $50,000 cash into the business:

```
Jan 1     Cash                        50,000
             Owner's Capital                     50,000
          (Owner initial investment)
```

## 2. Purchase on Account

Purchased inventory for $8,000 on credit:

```
Jan 5     Inventory                    8,000
             Accounts Payable                     8,000
          (Purchased inventory on account)
```

## 3. Cash Sale

Sold goods for $3,000 cash, cost was $1,800:

```
Jan 10    Cash                         3,000
             Sales Revenue                        3,000
          (Cash sale to customer)

Jan 10    Cost of Goods Sold           1,800
             Inventory                            1,800
          (Record cost of goods sold)
```

## 4. Payment to Supplier

Paid $5,000 to supplier on account:

```
Jan 15    Accounts Payable             5,000
             Cash                                 5,000
          (Payment to supplier)
```

## 5. Paid Expenses

Paid rent expense of $2,000:

```
Jan 20    Rent Expense                 2,000
             Cash                                 2,000
          (Paid monthly rent)
```

> **Practice:** Write entries for every transaction you encounter!

slides.title: Understanding T-Accounts
slides.content:
# T-Accounts Explained

## What is a T-Account?

A T-Account is a **visual representation** of an account that resembles the letter T. It shows debits on the left and credits on the right.

## T-Account Format

```
         Account Name
    -----------------------
    Debit    |    Credit
             |
    ++++     |    ----
             |
```

## Example: Cash Account

```
              Cash
    -----------------------
    Debit    |    Credit
             |
    50,000   |     4,000
     3,000   |     5,000
     2,000   |     2,000
    -------  |    -------
    55,000   |    11,000
             |
    Balance: 44,000 (Debit)
```

## Normal Balances

| Account Type | Normal Balance | Increases With |
|--------------|----------------|----------------|
| Assets | Debit | Debit |
| Liabilities | Credit | Credit |
| Equity | Credit | Credit |
| Revenue | Credit | Credit |
| Expenses | Debit | Debit |

## Calculating Balance

1. Total all debits
2. Total all credits
3. Subtract smaller from larger
4. Balance is on the side with larger total

> **Use T-Accounts** to visualize how transactions affect each account!

slides.title: T-Account Transaction Analysis
slides.content:
# Analyzing Transactions with T-Accounts

## Transaction: Purchased Equipment for $20,000
- Paid $8,000 cash
- Balance on account

### Step 1: Identify Accounts
- Equipment (Asset) - increases
- Cash (Asset) - decreases
- Accounts Payable (Liability) - increases

### Step 2: Determine Debit/Credit
- Equipment increases = Debit
- Cash decreases = Credit
- Accounts Payable increases = Credit

### Step 3: Draw T-Accounts

```
        Equipment              Cash           Accounts Payable
    ---------------     ---------------     ---------------
    Dr    |    Cr       Dr    |    Cr       Dr    |    Cr
          |                   |                   |
    20,000|            Bal   |   8,000           |   12,000
          |            30,000|                   |
    ------            -------                    -------
    20,000            Bal: 22,000                12,000
```

## Verification

- Debits: $20,000 (Equipment)
- Credits: $8,000 (Cash) + $12,000 (A/P) = $20,000
- **Balanced!**

## Using T-Accounts for Complex Transactions

T-Accounts help you:
- Visualize the double-entry effect
- Verify debits equal credits
- Track running balances
- Prepare for posting to ledger

> **Tip:** Draw T-Accounts for complex transactions before recording!

slides.title: The General Ledger
slides.content:
# The General Ledger

## What is a General Ledger?

The general ledger is the **master accounting record** containing all accounts used by a company. It is where journal entries are posted.

## Purpose

- **Organize** all accounts in one place
- **Track** the balance of each account
- **Prepare** trial balance and financial statements
- **Provide** audit trail

## General Ledger Account Format

```
Account: Cash                                  Account No: 101
--------------------------------------------------------------
Date     Description      Ref   Debit    Credit   Balance
--------------------------------------------------------------
Jan 1    Owner investment  J1   50,000            50,000 Dr
Jan 5    Supplies purchase J1             500    49,500 Dr
Jan 10   Service revenue   J2    3,000           52,500 Dr
Jan 15   Rent payment      J2            2,000   50,500 Dr
```

## Key Elements

| Element | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| Date | When transaction occurred |
| Description | Brief explanation |
| Ref (Reference) | Journal page number |
| Debit | Amount debited |
| Credit | Amount credited |
| Balance | Running account balance |

## Chart of Accounts

Accounts are organized by category:
- 100s - Assets
- 200s - Liabilities
- 300s - Equity
- 400s - Revenue
- 500s - Expenses

> **The ledger is the heart of the accounting system!**

slides.title: Subsidiary Ledgers
slides.content:
# Subsidiary Ledgers

## What is a Subsidiary Ledger?

A subsidiary ledger contains **detailed information** supporting a control account in the general ledger.

## Common Subsidiary Ledgers

### Accounts Receivable Subsidiary Ledger
Detailed records for each customer:

```
Customer: ABC Company
------------------------------------------------------
Date     Description      Debit    Credit   Balance
------------------------------------------------------
Jan 5    Invoice 1001     2,000             2,000
Jan 15   Payment                   1,500      500
Jan 20   Invoice 1025     3,000             3,500
```

### Accounts Payable Subsidiary Ledger
Detailed records for each supplier:

```
Vendor: XYZ Suppliers
------------------------------------------------------
Date     Description      Debit    Credit   Balance
------------------------------------------------------
Jan 3    Purchase                  5,000    5,000
Jan 10   Payment          3,000             2,000
Jan 18   Purchase                  4,000    6,000
```

## Control Account Relationship

```
    General Ledger              Subsidiary Ledger
    ---------------            ------------------
    Accounts Receivable   =    Customer A  $2,000
    Control: $8,500            Customer B  $3,500
                               Customer C  $3,000
                               ----------
                               Total:      $8,500
```

## Benefits of Subsidiary Ledgers

- Detailed customer/vendor information
- Easier to manage individual accounts
- Reduces clutter in general ledger
- Provides control through reconciliation

> **Reconcile** subsidiary ledgers to control accounts regularly!

slides.title: Ledger Quiz
slides.content: Test your understanding of ledgers!
slides.quizQuestion: What is the relationship between a control account and its subsidiary ledger?
quizOptions: The subsidiary ledger total should equal the control account balance
The control account shows more detail than the subsidiary ledger

slides.title: The Posting Process
slides.content:
# Posting from Journal to Ledger

## What is Posting?

Posting is the process of **transferring entries** from the journal to individual accounts in the ledger.

## Step-by-Step Posting

### Step 1: Locate the Ledger Account
Find the account in the general ledger.

### Step 2: Enter the Date
Record the date of the transaction.

### Step 3: Enter the Reference
Record the journal page number (e.g., J1).

### Step 4: Enter the Amount
- Enter debits in the debit column
- Enter credits in the credit column

### Step 5: Calculate New Balance
Update the running balance.

## Example

**Journal Entry:**
```
Jan 15    Supplies                   500
             Cash                            500
          (Purchased office supplies)
```

**Posted to Supplies Account:**
```
Account: Supplies                              No: 125
------------------------------------------------------
Date     Description      Ref   Debit   Credit  Balance
------------------------------------------------------
Jan 15   Purchase         J1      500           500 Dr
```

**Posted to Cash Account:**
```
Account: Cash                                  No: 101
------------------------------------------------------
Date     Description      Ref   Debit   Credit  Balance
------------------------------------------------------
Jan 1    Beg Balance           10,000          10,000 Dr
Jan 15   Supplies         J1             500    9,500 Dr
```

> **Cross-reference:** The journal reference (J1) helps trace entries back to their source!

slides.title: Adjusting Entries
slides.content:
# Adjusting Entries

## Purpose of Adjusting Entries

Made at **period end** to ensure:
- Revenues are recorded when earned
- Expenses are recorded when incurred
- Assets and liabilities are correctly stated

## Four Categories of Adjustments

### 1. Prepaid Expenses (Deferrals)

Advance payment that becomes expense:

```
Dec 31   Insurance Expense         1,000
            Prepaid Insurance               1,000
         (One month insurance expired)
```

### 2. Unearned Revenues (Deferrals)

Advance receipt that becomes revenue:

```
Dec 31   Unearned Revenue          500
            Service Revenue                  500
         (Services performed on advance)
```

### 3. Accrued Expenses

Expense incurred but not yet paid:

```
Dec 31   Salary Expense           3,000
            Salaries Payable               3,000
         (Salaries earned but unpaid)
```

### 4. Accrued Revenues

Revenue earned but not yet received:

```
Dec 31   Accounts Receivable       800
            Interest Revenue                 800
         (Interest earned but not received)
```

## Additional Adjustments

### Depreciation
```
Dec 31   Depreciation Expense     2,000
            Accumulated Depreciation        2,000
```

### Bad Debt Estimate
```
Dec 31   Bad Debt Expense           500
            Allowance for Doubtful Accts      500
```

> **Never skip adjusting entries** - they ensure accurate financial statements!

slides.title: Adjusting Entry Calculations
slides.content:
# Calculating Adjustments

## Prepaid Expense Example

**Situation:** On October 1, paid $12,000 for 12 months of insurance. Adjusting on December 31.

**Calculation:**
- Monthly insurance: $12,000 / 12 = $1,000
- Months expired (Oct, Nov, Dec): 3 months
- Amount to expense: $1,000 x 3 = $3,000

**Entry:**
```
Dec 31   Insurance Expense        3,000
            Prepaid Insurance              3,000
```

## Depreciation Example

**Situation:** Equipment cost $24,000, 5-year life, no salvage value. Full year adjustment.

**Calculation:**
- Annual depreciation: $24,000 / 5 = $4,800

**Entry:**
```
Dec 31   Depreciation Expense     4,800
            Accumulated Depreciation       4,800
```

## Accrued Salary Example

**Situation:** Weekly payroll is $5,000 paid every Friday. December 31 is a Wednesday.

**Calculation:**
- Daily salary: $5,000 / 5 = $1,000
- Days accrued (Mon, Tue, Wed): 3 days
- Amount to accrue: $1,000 x 3 = $3,000

**Entry:**
```
Dec 31   Salary Expense           3,000
            Salaries Payable              3,000
```

## Unearned Revenue Example

**Situation:** Received $6,000 on November 1 for 6 months service. Adjusting December 31.

**Calculation:**
- Monthly revenue: $6,000 / 6 = $1,000
- Months earned (Nov, Dec): 2 months
- Amount earned: $1,000 x 2 = $2,000

**Entry:**
```
Dec 31   Unearned Revenue         2,000
            Service Revenue               2,000
```

slides.content: Test your adjustment calculations!
slides.quizQuestion: A company pays $2,400 for a 2-year insurance policy on July 1. What is the adjusting entry amount for insurance expense on December 31 of the first year?

slides.title: Closing Entries Overview
slides.content:
# Closing Entries

## What are Closing Entries?

Closing entries are made at the **end of the accounting period** to:
- Transfer temporary account balances to permanent accounts
- Reset temporary accounts to zero
- Prepare for the next accounting period

## Temporary vs Permanent Accounts

| Temporary (Closed) | Permanent (Not Closed) |
|-------------------|------------------------|
| Revenue | Assets |
| Expenses | Liabilities |
| Dividends | Equity (Capital accounts) |

## The Closing Process

### Step 1: Close Revenue Accounts
Transfer all revenue to Income Summary:

```
Dec 31   Service Revenue         50,000
            Income Summary                50,000
```

### Step 2: Close Expense Accounts
Transfer all expenses to Income Summary:

```
Dec 31   Income Summary          35,000
            Rent Expense                  10,000
            Salary Expense                20,000
            Utilities Expense              5,000
```

### Step 3: Close Income Summary
Transfer net income/loss to Retained Earnings:

```
Dec 31   Income Summary          15,000
            Retained Earnings             15,000
         (Net Income: $50,000 - $35,000)
```

### Step 4: Close Dividends
Transfer dividends to Retained Earnings:

```
Dec 31   Retained Earnings        5,000
            Dividends                      5,000
```

> **After closing:** All temporary accounts have zero balances!

slides.title: Closing Entries Example
slides.content:
# Complete Closing Entry Example

## Pre-Closing Trial Balance (Partial)

```
Account                     Debit      Credit
----------------------------------------------
Service Revenue                        $80,000
Rent Expense               $24,000
Salary Expense              40,000
Utilities Expense            6,000
Depreciation Expense         5,000
Dividends                    8,000
Retained Earnings (Beg)                 25,000
```

## Closing Entry 1: Close Revenues

```
Dec 31   Service Revenue         80,000
            Income Summary                80,000
```

## Closing Entry 2: Close Expenses

```
Dec 31   Income Summary          75,000
            Rent Expense                  24,000
            Salary Expense                40,000
            Utilities Expense              6,000
            Depreciation Expense           5,000
```

## Closing Entry 3: Close Income Summary

Net Income = $80,000 - $75,000 = $5,000

```
Dec 31   Income Summary           5,000
            Retained Earnings              5,000
```

## Closing Entry 4: Close Dividends

```
Dec 31   Retained Earnings        8,000
            Dividends                      8,000
```

## Result

- Ending Retained Earnings: $25,000 + $5,000 - $8,000 = **$22,000**
- All temporary accounts are now **zero**

> **Verify:** Post-closing trial balance should show only permanent accounts!

slides.title: Post-Closing Trial Balance
slides.content:
# The Post-Closing Trial Balance

## Purpose

Prepared **after closing entries** to:
- Verify debits still equal credits
- Ensure all temporary accounts are zero
- Confirm books are ready for new period

## What It Contains

**Only Permanent Accounts:**
- Assets
- Liabilities
- Equity (with updated Retained Earnings)

**NOT Included:**
- Revenue
- Expenses
- Dividends

## Example Post-Closing Trial Balance

```
ABC Company
Post-Closing Trial Balance
December 31, 2024

Account                     Debit      Credit
----------------------------------------------
Cash                       $45,000
Accounts Receivable         30,000
Supplies                     5,000
Equipment                  100,000
Accumulated Depreciation               $25,000
Accounts Payable                        18,000
Notes Payable                           50,000
Common Stock                            65,000
Retained Earnings                       22,000
----------------------------------------------
Totals                    $180,000    $180,000
```

## Verification Checklist

- [ ] Debits equal credits
- [ ] No revenue accounts appear
- [ ] No expense accounts appear
- [ ] No dividend account appears
- [ ] Retained Earnings reflects net income/dividends

> **Ready for New Period:** The post-closing trial balance is the starting point for the next accounting cycle!

slides.title: Special Journals
slides.content:
# Special Journals

## Why Use Special Journals?

Special journals **simplify recording** high-volume, repetitive transactions.

## Four Common Special Journals

### 1. Sales Journal
Records all **credit sales**:

```
Sales Journal                                     Page S1
----------------------------------------------------------
Date    Customer    Invoice   Accts Rec Dr / Sales Rev Cr
----------------------------------------------------------
Jan 5   ABC Co.     1001         $2,000
Jan 8   XYZ Inc.    1002          3,500
Jan 12  MNO Ltd.    1003          1,500
----------------------------------------------------------
Month Total                      $7,000     (S1)
```

### 2. Purchases Journal
Records all **credit purchases**:

```
Purchases Journal                                 Page P1
----------------------------------------------------------
Date    Vendor      Terms    Inventory Dr / Accts Pay Cr
----------------------------------------------------------
Jan 3   Supplier A  n/30          $4,000
Jan 10  Supplier B  2/10,n/30      2,500
----------------------------------------------------------
Month Total                       $6,500     (P1)
```

### 3. Cash Receipts Journal
Records all **cash received**:
- Cash sales
- Collections from customers
- Other cash receipts

### 4. Cash Payments Journal
Records all **cash paid**:
- Payments to suppliers
- Cash purchases
- Expense payments

## Benefits

- Saves time with repetitive entries
- Reduces errors
- Allows division of labor
- Simplifies posting (monthly totals)

> **The General Journal** is still used for non-routine transactions!

slides.content: Test your understanding of special journals!

slides.title: Error Detection and Correction
slides.content:
# Finding and Fixing Errors

## Types of Errors

### Errors That Cause Trial Balance Imbalance

| Error Type | Description |
|------------|-------------|
| **Slide** | Decimal point moved (1,000 recorded as 100) |
| **Transposition** | Digits reversed (72 recorded as 27) |
| **One-sided** | Only debit or credit posted |
| **Math error** | Addition or subtraction mistake |

### Errors That Do NOT Affect Balance

| Error Type | Description |
|------------|-------------|
| **Wrong account** | Correct amount, wrong account |
| **Error of omission** | Transaction not recorded at all |
| **Error of reversal** | Debits and credits swapped |
| **Compensating** | Two errors that cancel out |

## Finding Errors

### Step 1: Calculate the Difference
Find the amount debits and credits are off by.

### Step 2: Look for That Exact Amount
Check if an entry for that amount was missed.

### Step 3: Divide by 2
If divisible by 2, look for entry on wrong side.

### Step 4: Divide by 9
If divisible by 9, likely a transposition error.

## Correcting Entries

**Never erase or delete!** Use correcting entries:

```
Original (Wrong):
  Supplies           500
      Cash                   500

Correction:
  Equipment          500
      Supplies               500
  (Correct entry from Supplies to Equipment)
```

> **Prevention is best:** Double-check entries before posting!

slides.title: Accounting Cycle Review
slides.content:
# The Complete Accounting Cycle

## The Nine Steps

### During the Period:

**Step 1: Analyze Transactions**
- Identify accounts affected
- Determine debit/credit

**Step 2: Journalize**
- Record in general journal
- Use proper format

**Step 3: Post to Ledger**
- Transfer to individual accounts
- Update balances

### At Period End:

**Step 4: Unadjusted Trial Balance**
- List all account balances
- Verify debits = credits

**Step 5: Adjusting Entries**
- Accruals and deferrals
- Journalize and post

**Step 6: Adjusted Trial Balance**
- Reflects all adjustments
- Ready for statements

**Step 7: Financial Statements**
- Income Statement
- Statement of Retained Earnings
- Balance Sheet

**Step 8: Closing Entries**
- Close temporary accounts
- Transfer to retained earnings

**Step 9: Post-Closing Trial Balance**
- Verify permanent account balances
- Ready for new period

## Cycle Frequency

| Period | Steps Performed |
|--------|-----------------|
| Daily | Steps 1-3 |
| Monthly | Steps 4-6 (sometimes 7) |
| Annually | All 9 steps |

> **The cycle repeats** every accounting period!

slides.title: Summary and Key Takeaways
slides.content:
# Congratulations! Summary

You have completed the **Journal Entries and Ledgers** lesson!

## Key Concepts Mastered

### Journal Entries
- Debits listed first, credits indented
- Total debits must equal total credits
- Include date, accounts, amounts, description

### T-Accounts
- Visual representation of accounts
- Left side = Debit, Right side = Credit
- Useful for transaction analysis

### Ledgers
- **General Ledger:** Master record of all accounts
- **Subsidiary Ledgers:** Detailed supporting records
- Always reconcile subsidiary to control accounts

### Adjusting Entries
- Made at period end
- Four types: Prepaid, Unearned, Accrued expenses, Accrued revenues

### Closing Entries
- Reset temporary accounts to zero
- Transfer net income to retained earnings

## Quick Reference

| Process | Purpose |
|---------|--------|
| Journalizing | Record transactions |
| Posting | Transfer to ledger |
| Adjusting | Ensure accuracy |
| Closing | Prepare for new period |

## What is Next?

Explore:
- Cost and managerial accounting
- Financial statement analysis
- Auditing procedures

> **Practice makes perfect:** The more entries you record, the more natural it becomes!
